facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 21, 1954, of the Madras High Court in W. P. No. 498 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 21, 1954, of the Madras High Court in W. P. No. 498 of 1952.

facts.text: Petition No. 130 of 1958 filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: With Petition No. 130 of 1958. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 21, 1960 by AYYANGAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. September 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.-

facts.text: Muthappa Chettiar is the appellant in Civil Appeal 107 of 1956 and petitioner in Petition 130/58.

anchor.surface_text: Muthappa Chettiar, the appellant in Civil Appeal 107 of 1956 was sought to be proceeded against for the recovery from him of Excess Profits Tax

facts.text: Muthappa Chettiar disputed legality of recovery proceedings for Excess Profits Tax and filed Writ Petition 498 of 1952 before Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: He disputed the legality of the recovery proceedings and filed Writ Petition 498 of 1952 before the High Court of Madras for the issue of a writ of prohibition

facts.text: Writ Petition 498 of 1952 was dismissed by Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was dismissed and Civil Appeal 107 of 1956 has been filed on special leave obtained from this Court.

facts.text: Appellant and Thyagrajan Chettiar were partners in firm named Muthappa Co. started in November 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and Thyagrajan Chettiar  impleaded as the second respondent in Civil Appeal 107 of 1956  were partners in a firm named Muthappa Co. started in November, 1940,

facts.text: Muthappa Co. was the managing agent of Saroja Mills Ltd. in Coimbatore district.

anchor.surface_text: and the firm was the managing agent of a textile Mill called Saroja Mills Ltd., in the Coimbatore district.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax assessment challenged for chargeable accounting periods: calendar year 1942 and January 1, 1943 to March 4, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment which is under challenge is for the Excess Profits Tax liability of this managing agency business and the relevant chargeable accounting periods are the calendar year 1942 and the broken period January 1, 1943, to March 4, 1943.

facts.text: Income-Tax liability for same periods assessed by Income-Tax Officer on March 15, 1948 under s. 23(5)(b) of Income-tax Act, 1922; appellant paid his share, no dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The liability of the firm to Income-Tax for the same periods was assessed by the Income-Tax Officer by his orders dated March 15, 1948, by applying the provisions of s. 23 5  b  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, arid the appellant paid, when demanded, his share of the tax and there is number numberdispute about the propriety of that assessment.

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax assessment completed by Excess Profits Tax Officer on March 31, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The income of the managing agency business was companyputed for Excess Profits Tax at the same figure as for assessment to Income Tax, and the assessment for the two chargeable accounting periods was companypleted by the Excess Profits Tax Officer by his order dated March 31, 1951,

facts.text: Assessment notices served only on Thyagrajan Chettiar, the managing partner.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the assessment was admittedly companypleted by serving, the prescribed numberices on Thyagrajan Chettiar alone, who according to the terms of the partnership between the parties was the managing partner.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed dissolution of firm as from March 4, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: But it was urged that there had been a dissolution of the firm as and from March 4, 1943, that thereafter the partnership ceased to exist,

facts.text: Thyagrajan Chettiar published notice of dissolution on March 4, 1943 in newspaper Hindu and informed Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Thyagrajan Chettiar published in the newspaper Hindu a numberice announcing the dissolution of the firm as and from March 4, 1943, and followed it up by informing the Income Tax Officer of this circumstance.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer enquired from appellant about dissolution; appellant replied on February 1, 1945 denying dissolution, stating suit pending in Coimbatore Sub-Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Income Tax Officer wrote to the appellant enquiring whether the firm of Muthappa Co. had been dissolved and if so from what date. By letter dated February 1, 1945, the appellant replied I wish to inform you that Messrs. Muthappa Co. has been formed as per the deed of partnership dated November 4, 1940,

facts.text: Appellant filed suit in Coimbatore Sub-Court contesting validity of dissolution notice of March 4, 1943; Subordinate Judge upheld dissolution in 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In line with the position taken up by him, disputing that the firm had been dissolved by the acts or companyduct of Thyagrajan Chettiar, the appellant filed a suit in the Sub-Court at Coimbatore companytesting the validity of Thyagrajan Chettiars numberice of dissolution dated March 4, 1943,

facts.text: Appeal from Subordinate Judge's 1948 judgment allowed by High Court in 1953, fixing dissolution date as March 10, 1949; further appeal pending in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge upheld the validity of the dissolution by Thyagrajan Chettiar in 1943. From this judgment rendered in 1948 the appellant preferred an appeal to the High Court. This appeal was heard in 1953 when the High Court allowed the appeal and fixed the date of dissolution as on March 10, 1949.

facts.text: At time of Excess Profits Tax assessment in 1951, appeal against Subordinate Judge's judgment was pending in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It was companymon ground that at the date the Excess Profits Tax Officer started proceedings for assessment, the appellant had filed an appeal against the judgment of the Subordinate Judge in O. S. 50 of 1946 and the same was pending in the High Court

facts.text: Managing agency business income computed at Rs. 1,02,219 for calendar year 1942 and Rs. 6,387 for Jan 1 to March 4, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The business income of the managing agency of Muthappa Co. was companyputed at Rs. 1,02,219 for the 1st chargeable accounting period, viz., the calender year 1942, and at Rs. 6,387 for the broken period January 1, 1943, to March 4, 1943.

facts.text: Saroja Mills withheld Rs. 89,137 of remuneration due to dispute over obligations.

anchor.surface_text: The sum of which immediate payment was thus withheld was Rs. 89,137.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer overruled objection to inclusion of withheld amount as income, as Mills claimed deduction of full amount.

anchor.surface_text: This objection was overruled on the ground that the Mills had never disputed that the entire amount of Rs. one lakh odd was due by them to the firm and in fact had claimed to deduct that entire sum as part of their business expenditure.

facts.text: No notice of demand under s.29 Income Tax Act served specifically on appellant; served on Thyagrajan Chettiar.

anchor.surface_text: It was further urged that as in the present case there had been numbernotice of demand under s. 29 of the Income Tax Act specifically addressed to and served on theappellant,

facts.text: Recovery proceedings under s.46 Income Tax Act initiated against appellant.

issues.text: Whether the appellant is precluded from pleading that the firm had been dissolved at the date of the assessment in 1951 and from raising any objection to the representative character of Thyagrajan Chettiar

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there are two answers to this submission, either of which would suffice to reject the appellants plea  1  That on the facts of the present case the appellant is precluded from pleading that the firm had been dissolved at the date of the assessment in 1951 and from raising any objection to the representative character of Thyagrajan Chettiar,

issues.text: Whether on a proper construction of the provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, even if the firm of Muthappa Co. should be held to have been dissolved before 1951 when the order of assessment was passed, the assessment of the managing agency business to Excess Profits Tax was properly and legally effected by notice to Thyagrajan Chettiar

anchor.surface_text: 2  That on a proper construction of the provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, even if the firm of Muthappa Co. should be held to have been dissolved before 1951 when the order of assessment was passed, the assessment of the managing agency business to Excess Profits Tax was properly and legally effected by notice to Thyagrajan Chettiar.

issues.text: Whether the assessment to Excess Profits Tax was valid despite notices served only on the managing partner after the alleged dissolution of the firm

anchor.surface_text: the assessment was admittedly completed by serving, the prescribed notices on Thyagrajan Chettiar alone, who according to the terms of the partnership between the parties was the managing partner. But it was urged that there had been a dissolution of the firm as and from March 4, 1943, that thereafter the partnership ceased to exist, and with it the mutual agency between the partners, with the result that Thyagrajan Chettiar could not represent the firm which had ceased to exist nor the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the disputed remuneration withheld by the Mills could be included as income of the firm for Excess Profits Tax assessment

anchor.surface_text: but this would make no difference to the tax-liability of the firm, since the firms accounts were made on the mercantile basis. The Mills raised a dispute that the managing agents had not fulfilled certain of the obligations undertaken by them in regard to the extension of the mills by increasing the spindle age, by reason of which default they claimed to have suffered a loss of income and for.

issues.text: Whether the Excess Profits Tax assessed could be validly recovered from the appellant by resort to the machinery for collection provided by s. 46 of the Income Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: the machinery for collection provided by s. 46 of the Income Tax Act. The argument of learned Counsel for the appellant in regard to this point ,as on the following lines Sections 45 to 47 of the Income Tax Act, 1922, which provide for the recovery of Income-tax by coercive process, no doubt apply for the recovery of Excess Profits Tax by virtue of their inclusion in s. 21 of the Excess Profits Tax Act as provisions applicable to the latter Act,

issues.text: Whether the appellant was an assessee or only a person liable to pay the tax under s. 29 of the Income Tax Act, requiring a specific notice of demand

anchor.surface_text: It was further urged that as in the present case there had been no notice of demand under s. 29 of the Income Tax Act specifically addressed to and served on the appellant, he could not become an assessee in default neither would the tax payable by him become an arrear as to permit the invocation of the coercive process under s. 46 (2) for recovery.

issues.text: Whether coercive process under ss. 45-47 applies only to assessees in default or also to other persons liable to pay tax

anchor.surface_text: or whether the expression assessee when it occurs in ss. 45 to 47 should be understood as defined in s. 2 (2) as including every person by whom tax is payable , since we are clearly of the Opinion that the appellant was an assessee .

arguments.claim: Assessment to Excess Profits Tax is invalid because the firm was dissolved as from March 4, 1943, partnership ceased to exist, mutual agency ended, and notices were served only on Thyagrajan Chettiar who could not represent the firm or the appellant

anchor.surface_text: But it was urged that there had been a dissolution of the firm as and from March 4, 1943, that thereafter the partnership ceased to exist, and with it the mutual agency between the partners, with the result that Thyagrajan Chettiar could not represent the firm which had ceased to exist nor the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: and the rights of the partners are also retracted therein. But Mr. Thyagrajan Chettiar my partner has acted deliberately beyond the scope of the partn

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant precluded by prior denial of dissolution and pending litigation; alternatively, valid under EPTA as business is unit of assessment and notice to managing partner sufficient even post-dissolution per ss.13,14,44,63

arguments.claim: Appellant is precluded from pleading dissolution of firm at time of 1951 assessment or objecting to Thyagrajan Chettiar's representative capacity due to prior denial to ITO and ongoing suit making matter res sub-judice

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there are two answers to this submission, either of which would suffice to reject the appellants plea  1  That on the facts of the present case the appellant is precluded from pleading that the firm had been dissolved at the date of the assessment in 1951 and from raising any objection to the representative character of Thyagrajan Chettiar,

arguments.claim: Even if firm dissolved before 1951 assessment, assessment valid as business (not firm) is unit of assessment under EPTA; notice to Thyagrajan Chettiar as managing partner sufficient per ss.13,44 (modified),63 IT Act applied via s.21 EPTA; partners jointly/severally liable per s.14 EPTA

anchor.surface_text: 2  That on a proper construction of the provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, even if the firm of Muthappa Co. should be held to have been dissolved before 1951 when the order of assessment was passed, the assessment of the managing agency business to Excess Profits Tax was properly and legally effected by notice to Thyagrajan Chettiar.

arguments.claim: Coercive recovery under ss.45-47 IT Act applies only to assessees in default, not to 'other persons liable to pay tax' like partners; only suit possible

anchor.surface_text: That the procedure for recovery enacted in ss. 45 to 47 including s. 46 2  were confined in their application to assessees and assessees in default and did not apply to the class of other persons liable to pay the tax as against whom the filing of a suit for the recovery of the tax and the execution of decrees in such Suits was the only machinery through which the tax liability of this class could be enforced.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide as appellant held to be assessee

arguments.claim: Appellant is assessee under EPTA per s.21 proviso as partner in business to which Act applies; notice to managing partner under s.29 via s.63 binds him as assessee in default

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this case we do not consider it necessary to deal with the larger second question as to whether the expression assessee and assessee in default in ss. 45 46 of the Income Tax Act, 1922, should be held to be confined to assessees as distinguished from other persons liable to pay such tax as these expressions occur in s. 29 of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant denied dissolution to ITO in 1945, filed suit contesting it, appeal pending at assessment time rendering matter res sub-judice; cannot retrospectively challenge

holdings.text: On a proper construction of the provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, even if the firm of Muthappa Co. should be held to have been dissolved before 1951 when the order of assessment was passed, the assessment of the managing agency business to Excess Profits Tax was properly and legally effected by notice to Thyagrajan Chettiar

anchor.surface_text: 2  That on a proper construction of the provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, even if the firm of Muthappa Co. should be held to have been dissolved before 1951 when the order of assessment was passed, the assessment of the managing agency business to Excess Profits Tax was properly and legally effected by notice to Thyagrajan Chettiar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Business is unit of assessment under EPTA; ss.13,14,21,44,63 IT Act apply; notice to managing partner valid post-dissolution as partners jointly/severally liable; assessment as if undissolved firm

holdings.text: The notice served on Thyagrajan Chettiar was valid and was binding on the appellant and that there is no basis for challenging the legality of the assessment to Excess Profits Tax

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the passages extracted correctly express the legal position resulting from the relevant provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940. We, therefore, hold that the notice served on Thyagrajan Chettiar was valid and was binding on the appellant and that there is no basis for challenging the legality of the assessment to Excess Profits Tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Pandu Rao; EPTA provisions make service on partner sufficient even after dissolution

holdings.text: There are no legal grounds for impugning the validity of the order of assessment to Excess Profits Tax dated March 31, 1951

anchor.surface_text: We see no substance in the point urged. Learned Counsel referred us to the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. K. R. M. T. T. Thiagaraja Chetty Co.  1  and to the observations at p. We consider that the decision far from supporting the appellant is really against him. There are therefore no legal grounds for impugning

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mercantile accounting; income accrued despite withholding as Mills acknowledged liability and deducted full amount

holdings.text: The appellant was an assessee and assessee in default; notice of demand under s.29 served on managing partner binds him per s.63

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this case we do not consider it necessary to deal with the larger second question as to whether the expression assessee and assessee in default in ss. 45 46 of the Income Tax Act, 1922, should be held to be confined to assessees as distinguished from other persons liable to pay such tax as these expressions occur in s. 29 of the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per s.21 proviso EPTA, partner in business is assessee; s.63 deems service on partner as service on all

holdings.text: The proceedings for the recovery of the Excess Profits Tax could properly be taken under s.46 of the Income Tax Act and the order of the High Court dismissing the appellants petition for the issue of a writ of prohibition was correct

anchor.surface_text: the machinery for collection provided by s. 46 of the Income Tax Act. The argument of learned Counsel for the appellant in regard to this point ,as on the following lines Sections 45 to 47 of the Income Tax Act, 1922, which provide for the recovery of Income-tax by coercive process, no doubt apply for the recovery of Excess Profits Tax by virtue of their inclusion in s. 21 of the Excess Profits Tax Act as provisions applicable to the latter Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant assessee in default; coercive recovery valid without separate notice

precedents.citation: A. O. Pandu Rao v. Collector of Madras 1 1954 26 I.T. 99

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection learned Counsel for the appellant drew our attention to a decision of the Madras High Court in A. O. Pandu Rao v. Collector of Madras  1 , and stated that it was against him and directly companyered the point and if companyrect would leave numberscope for any further argument. In that case a firm companysisting of three partners carried on business under the name of P. Nagoji Rao Son, with one of them Gannu Rao as managing-partner. The chargeable accounting periods companycerned were the years from April 1, 1944 to March 31, 1946. There were quarrels among the partners which led to the filing of a suit on February 26, 1947, for dissolution and accounts by two of the partners against the managing-partner. The suit was decreed on November 14, 1947, declaring the firm dissolved as and from the institution of the suit-February 26, 1947. The assessment of the business to Excess Profits Tax was companypleted by numberices issued subsequent to that date to Gannu Rao as managing-partner and the order of assessment was passed on December 31, 1949, and a numberice of demand under s. 29 of the Income Tax Act was served on him. No demand numberices were served on the other two partners, but proceedings for the recovery of the tax were taken against them on the strength of the numberices served on Gannu Rao. These two partners moved the High Court  1   1954  26 I.T. 99.

precedents.case_name: A. O. Pandu Rao v. Collector of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Even after dissolution of a firm, Excess Profits Tax assessment of the business can be completed by serving notice on the managing partner during the chargeable period, as the business is the unit of assessment under the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, applying modified s. 44, s. 63 of Income-tax Act.
precedents.cited_holding: Notice to a partner is treated as notice to all; assessment can be made on dissolved firm as if undissolved using s. 63 machinery.

precedents.citation: Bose v. Manindra Lal Goswami 1 1957 33 I.T.R. 435, 447

anchor.surface_text: As observed by Chakravartti, C. J., in Bose v. Manindra Lal Goswami  1  It will thus be seen that in the case of excess profits tax, there is numberdifference in the method of assessment prescribed for the assessment of the profits of a running business and that prescribed for  1   1957  33 I.T.R. 435, 447. the assessment of the past profits of a business carried on by a firm, since dissolved.

precedents.cited_proposition: No difference in assessment method for running business or past profits of dissolved firm under Excess Profits Tax; assessment on partners jointly and severally in partnership name.
precedents.cited_holding: It will thus be seen that in the case of excess profits tax, there is no difference in the method of assessment prescribed for the assessment of the profits of a running business and that prescribed for the assessment of the past profits of a business carried on by a firm, since dissolved.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the passages extracted correctly express the legal position resulting from the relevant provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940. We, therefore, hold that the notice served on Thyagrajan Chettiar was valid and was binding on the appellant and that there is no basis for challenging the legality of the assessment to Excess Profits Tax.
The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
